For example, it would be possible to have one eye with better distance vision, and then have the second eye adjusted to offer better close vision, as long as it is tolerated.

title: Is it true that premium IOLs require laser-assisted surgery?
question: Do premium IOLs require laser-assisted surgery while traditional surgery with a blade is only for implanting basic monofocal IOLs?
answer: Having femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (FLACS) may be beneficial in some cases. However, FLACS not required in order to use premium or advanced technology intraocular lenses. All of these lenses may be used whether or not the surgery is standard or laser assisted.

title: Can I use Flomax after cataract surgery?
question: Can I use Flomax after cataract surgery ?
answer:
Yes and it will not interfere with your healing. You may be thinking how Flomax and similar medications (known as BPH medication or alpha-blockers) can affect the iris's (the colored part of your eye) muscles during the surgery.

Before surgery, tell your ophthalmologist that you take these medications, so they can prepare for any side effects that may arise from them. After the surgery, there is no issue taking these drugs as it relates to your operated eye(s).

answer_links.text: iris's (the colored part of your eye) muscles

title: Will radiation treatment affect my IOLs?
question: My breast cancer metastasized to the tissue of my orbits in both eyes and I'm noticing blurry vision, watering and burning sensation. Will radiation affect my IOLs?
answer: I'm sorry you're dealing with these problems. You can be rest assured that there is no evidence radiation treatment will affect your intraocular lenses .

title: Can I choose not to have an IOL?
question: Can one have a cataract removed without correcting vision? I am nearsighted with astigmatism but do a lot of close-up work. I don't mind wearing glasses and like being able to take off my glasses to see very up close and want to avoid the potential side effects of IOLs.
answer:
An important part of the discussion that should take place with your ophthalmologist before cataract surgery is how you would like to have your vision corrected. This includes the different intraocular lenses (or IOLs) that may be available to you, as well as the refractive target, which in your case is to remain nearsighted . A helpful way to think about this is where you would like your vision to have the best focus and how clear you would like it to be without glasses.

An experienced ophthalmologist should be able to make recommendations with your preferences in mind.

title: Can I get monovision glasses after cataract surgery?
question: I had cataract surgery with one eye corrected for distance and the other for near vision. After many years my distance is not so good. Can I get monovision glasses to correct this?
answer: This really depends on your correction, but if you are going to wear glasses in any way to correct your vision, I would recommend progressive lenses that will correct both eyes for all distances. If you would like monovision without glasses , contact lenses are the preferred option.

answer_links.text: If you would like monovision without glasses

title: Can you have cataract surgery too early in the disease process?
question: Is there such a thing as having cataract surgery too early in the natural history of the disease process? I may live another 30 years after cataract surgery and wonder what sort of ophthalmic advancements may occur after surgery at 65.
answer:
Technology is always evolving. However, if your cataract interferes with any of your daily activities , then I would recommend surgery with the current available technology.

Today's technology delivers excellent results that will endure. If clearer vision can improve your quality of life now, why wait another 10 years or more?

answer_links.text: However, if your cataract interferes with any of your daily activities

title: Why can I see well with glasses after cataract surgery on one eye?
question: I just had cataract surgery on my left (dominant) eye with a lens for distant vision . I'm wearing my old glasses (-4.00 in each lens) and I can see distance objects very well, even though the left eye has a distance lens implanted. Why is that? I thought the left eye wouldn't be able to function with the glasses.
answer:
You might be suppressing the distance vision in your operated eye while wearing your glasses and using your unoperated right eye for distance.

If your distance vision is fine without glasses, you might consider setting the right eye for near vision (called monovision) if you have cataract surgery in this eye in the future. However, if your distance vision without glasses is not great, then the right eye should be set for distance vision as well, leaving you more dependent on reading glasses for near vision with both eyes.

It is somewhat unusual (although not impossible) to suppress the dominant eye when viewing distance, and this suggests that perhaps your right eye is actually dominant, or that you don't have a heavily weighted dominant eye.

answer_links.text: setting the right eye for near vision (called monovision)

title: Could my blurry vision already mean I have a PCO?
question: Within a week of cataract surgery , my distance vision is blurrier with more sunlight. Could I have a PCO already?
answer: Yes, you may have early PCO or posterior capsule opacification (when the capsule holding your eye's lens becomes cloudy after cataract surgery). Sometimes early deposits on the posterior capsule resolve on their own. If this is the cause and does not resolve itself, a YAG capsulotomy can fix the problem at about three months after your surgery .

answer_links.text: a YAG capsulotomy can fix the problem at about three months after your surgery

title: Can I improve my amblyopia after infant cataract surgery?
question:
I had a cataract removed as an infant , which was replaced with a monofocal IOL . At 23, that eye remains slightly amblyopic .

If adults can improve their amblyopia after damaging their good eye, can this help me? And what would be the consequences of using an intentionally wrong prescription (contacts or glasses) to cloud the good eye? Would there potentially be any negative consequences of this?
answer:
It is so nice to hear of your good visual outcome from cataract surgery in infancy. At 23 years of age it would be unusual for any treatment to improve the vision further. Vision researchers continue to work on developing ways to reopen vision development.

On the other part of your question I do not believe there would be any harm to your good eye from some blur or patching but there is little good evidence that this would help your amblyopic eye (or an eye that failed to develop normal vision during childhood). It is true that if a patient with an amblyopic eye has severe or total vision loss in their “good” eye, then vision in the amblyopic eye may improve somewhat, but this rarely would result in “normal” vision.

title: Is it safe to have YAG with a PVD?
question: Is it safe to have YAG while you have PVD? It’s been 5 months since the PVD started.
answer:
The YAG laser used during a posterior capsulotomy poses no risk to the vitreous inside the eye or its age-related detachment process if already underway. However, YAG capsulotomy does carry a low but real risk of retinal tear (average risk is less than 1%) and this risk is greatest if the PVD (posterior vitreous detachment) is in process or has recently occurred.

Based on recent research it is typically recommended that you wait at least 6 months following a complete PVD before proceeding with YAG capsulotomy to decrease the risk of retinal tear and detachment . There may be special circumstances affecting the timing of your procedure so please discuss this question with your eye surgeon.

answer_links.text: The YAG laser used during a posterior capsulotomy poses
carry a low but real risk of retinal tear

title: Why do I feel a scratchy sensation in my eyelid after cataract surgery?
question: One month after cataract surgery , why do I feel a scratchy sensation in my eyelid?
answer: It is not uncommon to feel a bit of scratchiness after cataract surgery. Your eye might feel a bit dry , and you may have sensitivity to the post-surgical drops or the sutures if they were used to seal the incision. Please discuss this and any other symptoms with your surgeon.

answer_links.text: Your eye might feel a bit dry

title: How soon after cataract surgery can I try to get pregnant?
question: How soon after cataract surgery can I try to get pregnant?
answer: We have no evidence that drops that are used after cataract surgery have any effect on the fetus. However out of abundance of caution, you may want to wait until surgery is completed on the second eye and you’ve stopped taking any post-operative medication. This is usually 5 weeks after cataract surgery.

title: With cataract surgery, are there accommodations for those with mobility problems?
question: Are there accommodations for cataract surgery patients with mobility problems? My mother is overweight and we're told she needs to be removed from her wheelchair multiple times for testing. Are there workarounds to meet these testing requirements that allow her to stay in her chair?
answer:
While it is easiest if someone is able to transfer to an exam chair or surgical stretcher, some offices and surgery centers/hospitals are able to accommodate wheelchair-bound individuals who are unable to transfer.

You should discuss your concerns with your mother's ophthalmologist and/or office manager, as they may have such "workarounds." That said, sometimes referral to a different ophthalmologist is necessary and in the patient's best interest.

title: Why don't I see clearly with my left eye when closing the right after cataract surgery?
question: With mini-monovision after cataract surgery , I use my non-dominant left eye for distance. I wear driving glasses, which provide crisp distance vision and I am also able to see the dashboard clearly. I noticed, however, when I close my right eye, I cannot see clearly with my left. It is almost as if the monovision has been reversed. Is this a concern?
answer:
With monovision (or blended vision) , a person's "dominant" eye is typically corrected to see better at a distance, while their "non-dominant" eye is corrected to see better up close.

Glasses for driving usually correct both eyes to see better at a distance. If you are having trouble seeing clearly out of your left eye while wearing glasses, then have them checked by the optician who sold them to you. If the optician confirms the glasses were made correctly, then follow up with the eye care provider who wrote the glasses prescription to have this rechecked.

title: Can I use acetaminophen eye drops after surgery?
question: As I am allergic to NSAIDs, are there eye drops with acetaminophen I can use after cataract surgery?
answer:
There is no drop that contains acetaminophen.

Please note that topical NSAID (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) drops are not an absolute requirement for safe cataract surgery . If you are truly allergic to NSAIDs then talk to your surgeon about not using them topically. They will most likely say that that is fine.

answer_links.text: Please note that topical NSAID (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) drops

title: Does risk of IOL dislocation preclude YAG laser treatment?
question: Does a high risk of IOL dislocation in nearsighted eyes preclude laser capsulotomy treatment of PCO?
answer: It does not. If the intraocular lens (IOL) is currently stable and in place and there is clinically significant posterior capsule opacification (PCO) then a posterior capsulotomy is indicated and can and should be done.

title: Should an oculoplastic specialist examine my droopy eyelid before cataract surgery?
question: Should an oculoplastic specialist examine my ptosis before cataract surgery ?
answer:
It is ideal, but not mandatory, for an oculoplastic surgeon to evaluate a droopy eyelid (ptosis) before cataract surgery.

It’s important to understand the cause of the ptosis, as there can be refractive changes from severe ptosis that may impact IOL (intraocular lens) selection. The ptosis may worsen after cataract surgery. Ultimately, it is up to the patient and the discretion of the cataract surgeon to determine timing of referral to an oculoplastic surgeon.

title: Should an oil bubble be used if you have an artificial lens?
question: Should an oil bubble to hold a detached retina in place be used if there is an artificial lens in that same eye?
answer: Yes, having an artificial intraocular lens (IOL) does not prevent the use of silicone oil in the eye to help repair a retinal detachment . Silicone oil is often used for retinal detachment repair in eyes with IOLs.

title: At what level should blood pressure be prior to cataract surgery?
question: What should a person’s blood pressure be before cataract surgery and what is considered too high?
answer:
In general, since cataract surgery is a voluntary procedure, most surgeons would choose not to operate if there are medical problems that are found to be uncontrolled. Most surgeons would hold off on surgery if the diastolic blood pressure is above 100 or systolic blood pressure is above 160 to 180 or so. The other factor to consider is the patient’s baseline blood pressure. If the blood pressure is significantly higher than baseline then one must consider whether the patient’s blood pressure is safely under control. Sometimes anticipation of surgery can cause a spike in blood pressure on arrival to the surgery center, which will then decrease after relaxing for a while.

This question was originally answered on Jun. 2, 2015.

title: Why does my other eye seem worse after cataract surgery on the fellow eye?
question: After having an IOL implanted in my "bad" eye , the "good" eye now seems more cloudy, like the old eye used to. Is that because the eye that had cataract surgery is now highlighting the fellow eye's previously unnoticed weakness?
answer: Yes, most likely both eyes had cataracts and now that the first eye has been corrected, it lets you know that the “better” eye actually had issues as well. Plan to get the other eye done and you will be more in balance and happier with your vision.

answer_links.text: Yes, most likely both eyes had cataracts

title: If I have pathological myopia, would it be preferable to maximize near distance instead of far distance in lens choice?
question: I have pathological myopia . I am wondering if it would be preferable to maximize near distance instead of far distance in lens choice , as my eye will continue to elongate after cataract surgery.
answer: It is doubtful that your eye will continue to elongate but you may experience some atrophy in the pigment in the central part of the retina . It is very important that you consult with a retina specialist yearly. Because it is the lens that will make you more myopic as you get older, and it is this lens that will be removed by cataract surgery , you are free to pick whatever distance you wish for correction.

title: Can I expect a secondary cataract on the other eye if it happened on the first eye?
question: I had secondary cataract soon after cataract surgery on one eye and did YAG. Now that I’ve done the other eye, am I more likely to get secondary cataract again?
answer:
Secondary cataract (also known as posterior capsule opacification) is when the tissue (lens capsule) that once held your eye’s natural lens becomes cloudy after cataract surgery . It is common and can take months or years to develop. In my experience what happens in one eye is similar to what happens in the other. But that is not always the case. The type of cataract, specifics about the particular surgery, and the post-operative course also play an important role and this may differ between the two eyes.

Nonetheless, I wouldn't be overly concerned because modern YAG laser treatment (or posterior capsulotomy) is very safe and effective .

answer_links.text: the tissue (lens capsule) that once held your eye’s natural lens
YAG laser treatment (or posterior capsulotomy) is very safe and effective

title: I accidentally rubbed my eye two weeks after my cataract surgery. Do you think this caused any damage?
question: I accidentally rubbed my eye two weeks after my cataract surgery . Do you think this caused any damage?
answer: Rubbing your eye gently two weeks after cataract surgery is unlikely to cause harm to the eye. Vigorous rubbing, however, could cause a corneal abrasion and even damage the surgical wound. If you have any pain or change in vision, please see your surgeon right away. This question was originally answered on Feb. 21, 2014.

title: Why am I seeing streaks of light after cataract surgery?
question: I just had cataract surgery and when I went outside at night I saw streams or long streaks of light across the outdoor lights everywhere I looked. Can it be corrected and will it go away over time?
answer:
Our pupils dilate in dim light, and this can cause or increase optical aberrations such as you describe, especially following cataract surgery. Still, there are potential genuine issues associated with these symptoms. You should see your ophthalmologist and have them confirm that the intraocular lens is ideally centered and your eye is in good condition.

This question was originally answered on Feb. 21, 2014.

title: Should I go without reading glasses if I have a multifocal IOL?
question: during the surgery a few days ago. Will it help my brain adjust to near vision by not wearing reading glasses or are there other ways to help my brain adapt to near vision better?
answer:
This would depend on the other eye. If your multifocal IOL was just recently inserted then you may need some time for the vision to clear at all distances. Also, if your other eye requires spectacles to read this may be a barrier to reading without glasses. Multifocal IOLs tend to work best after being inserted in both eyes. Multifocal IOLs are not guaranteed to eliminate the need for spectacles at all distances, and there may be times when glasses may help for distance, reading or in between.

To your question, I do find that if the reading is good enough without using glasses, then not using them may help you acclimate to your new ability to read and allow the brain to choose the near image to focus on.

title: Should I have cataract surgery in my second eye if my vision is still good?
question: I had cataract surgery performed in my right eye five months ago without complications and excellent results. I can still see clearly with my left eye which has not been operated on. Should I go ahead and have cataract surgery in my left eye too even though vision in it is still good?
answer: Cataract surgery is done to improve vision that interferes with quality of life issues, like working or driving. If the lens in the fellow eye is not interfering with your quality of life, but a patient wishes to have it removed, this would usually be considered an elective procedure. This means it is not covered by health insurance. Therefore, if the vision in your left eye “is still good,” you may want to consider delaying surgery until your eye develops a cataract such that it interferes with your quality of life. In certain circumstances, an ophthalmologist may recommend cataract surgery when the patient does not complain of vision problems – surgery to balance the eyes may decrease the risk of falls (which can cause hip fractures) or decrease the risk of angle closure glaucoma . A discussion with your ophthalmologist after a thorough in-person exam will help you reach a decision that is best for you.

title: Should I have skin tags removed before cataract surgery?
question: Should I have eyelid skin tags (“benign,” or non-cancerous, small growths of the skin) removed before cataract surgery ?
answer: Please ask your surgeon what her preference may be. In general. the removal of a benign skin tag is not a preoperative requirement. Unless, of course, you have a habit of rubbing your eyes in the area of the skin tags, which could cause problems after surgery.

title: Should I use a toric lens if I have had corneal transplants?
question: I have two corneal grafts (transplants) and need cataract surgery . My surgeon would implant toric intraocular lenses (IOLs) for astigmatism (irregularly shaped cornea) as part of the procedure. In discussing the risks involved he says that I eventually may need new corneal transplants because of the continual changing nature of my corneas. If so, the implanted lenses would be a total mismatch for the new corneas. Is it possible to remove IOLs after a prolonged period such as 10 years? Is this ever done?
answer: This is an extremely complicated and nuanced decision. If your grafts are clear and stable and the astigmatism is regular then I would consider a toric intraocular lens. If the grafts are unstable, meaning changing or beginning to fail and repeat transplants are imminent then I would not consider a toric IOL. And, yes, implants can be exchanged but the longer they have been in the more difficult that may be.

title: Should patients with pseudoexfoliation syndrome have laser cataract surgery?
question: Should patients with pseudoexfoliation syndrome have laser cataract surgery ?
answer:
Pseudoexfoliation of the lens capsule is when the eye’s natural lens and the supporting structures (zonules) which hold the lens in place are weakened. Modern cataract surgery and placement of the intraocular lens (or IOL, the artificial lens that replaces the cataract) are dependent on the strength of these structures. Pseudoexfoliation can vary in severity and impact on these structures.

Successful cataract surgery and IOL placement can be performed safely with pseudoexfoliation, but it is an added risk factor for a safe result. Laser-assisted cataract surgery can minimize the stress of these structures and some ophthalmologists feel it results in a safer operation. This is an area of disagreement among ophthalmologists.

answer_links.text: intraocular lens (or IOL, the artificial lens that replaces the cataract)

title: Should you have YAG before having cataract surgery on the second eye?
question: If a patient has PCO (posterior capsule opacification) in her eye after cataract surgery, should that eye be repaired with YAG laser (or posterior capsulotomy) first, or should I have cataract surgery on the fellow eye first?
answer: If the PCO (when vision becomes cloudy shortly after cataract surgery) is bothering your vision significantly, have the YAG first. With YAG, or posterior capsulotomy , a laser makes an opening in the cloudy capsule holding your artificial lens and restores clear vision. It literally takes less than a minute with no restrictions afterward. You can plan to have the cataract surgery in the next days or week. There’s no harm in waiting to have the YAG either.

title: Is routine pre-operative medical clearance needed before cataract surgery?
question: Is routine pre-operative medical clearance needed before cataract surgery?
answer: Routine pre-operative clearance for cataract surgery (which is usually done under local pain killer with IV sedation) is not usually necessary unless you have some serious health issues. It is required by the medical or health boards in some states.

title: How can I reduce puffiness under my eye after cataract surgery?
question: Are there any tips to reduce puffiness under the eye after cataract surgery on a dense or mature lens?
answer: Patients often notice puffiness under their eyes after cataract surgery. The surgery does not cause the puffiness, but enhanced vision following the surgery allows you to see the aging characteristic. Fortunately, there is cosmetic surgery called lower blepharoplasty to improve the appearance of the puffiness.

answer_links.text: Fortunately, there is cosmetic surgery called lower blepharoplasty

title: Can I wear makeup the same day I have a YAG posterior capsulotomy?
question: Can I wear makeup the same day I have a YAG posterior capsulotomy ?
answer: There shouldn't be a problem wearing makeup before a YAG procedure. But be to sure ask the ophthalmologist who will be doing the procedure for their specific guidance.

title: What are the odds of getting halos or star bursts from multifocal IOLs?
question: I am trying to decide whether to go with monofocal IOLs or multifocal IOLs . Is there any way to assess the odds of getting halos or star bursts which do not resolve? Is there any significant difference between brands of multifocal lenses in terms of halo or star bursts which do not resolve?
answer: There is no specific test to assess the risk of halos, as every patient notices some halo/glare after the surgery. For most, this will decrease over the first three months. Some surgeons feel that certain corneal abnormalities found on measurements taken before the surgery can lead to more halo/glare after surgery but this is not absolute. Ask your surgeon about this. I would have your surgeon check this and all other pre-operative measurements to see if multifocal IOLs are a good option for you. Some doctors feel that certain multifocal lenses perform better than others. Ask your ophthalmologist what might work best for you.

title: What are the risks of not removing a cataract?
question: What are some of the risks associated with not having a cataract removed? Can other damage occur as the cataract continues to get larger?
answer: The main risk of not having a cataract removed is that you will be living with compromised vision from the cataract that is known to result in a higher incidence of falls as well as other problems. If your vision is not bothersome and you feel you can get around and do all activities of daily living, there is no harm in waiting. It is possible to wait too long, making the cataract operation more difficult if the cataract becomes mature or very dense.

title: What can be done if one develops a cataract after getting an implantable contact lens?
question: What can be done if one develops a cataract after having an ICL (implantable contact lens) to cure myopia ?
answer: Cataract removal can be scheduled electively and should be like a regular cataract surgery. The ICL will be removed and then the cataract is removed. The newly implanted artificial lens (IOL) replaces the ICL. If additional correction is needed, glasses, contact lenses or refractive surgery can finetune the refraction.

answer_links.text: Cataract removal can be scheduled electively

title: What can I use for my red, itchy eyes after cataract surgery?
question: What can I use for my red, itchy eyes after cataract surgery?
answer:
There are several reasons that eyes can be red and itchy after cataract surgery .

In the first few weeks after surgery, the surgical incisions and medicated eye drops can cause irritation of the surface of the eye. Less common would be an actual allergic reaction to the eye drops. Later after surgery, the area of the incisions can still cause surface irritation, sometimes for several months. Most of these situations will improve with use of artificial tears (lubricant eye drops) to soothe the eyes.

Early after surgery, while the incisions are still healing, you should use a new bottle of artificial tears or purchase preservative-free tears (which come in small plastic vials rather than a bottle) to avoid placing contaminated drops on the eye. It is best to avoid products that have vasoconstrictors to relieve redness (drops to “get the red out”). Avoid using the tears within 15 minutes before or after your medicated surgical eye drops (this could dilute the medication and reduce its effectiveness).

If the lubricating drops do not help, or if the redness and itching are severe, you should contact your ophthalmologist immediately.

title: What does a rating of 4.5 for cataracts mean?
question: What does a rating of 4.5 for cataracts signify?
answer: All ophthalmologists have different “ratings” for grading the density of the cataract . In a 5-point system, this would be a very dense cataract which would normally need removal .

title: What happens if I get a cataract after I have an IOL implanted?
question: If IOLs (or intraocular artificial lenses that replace your eye’s natural lenses) are implanted as elective surgery, what is done if cataracts develop afterwards?
answer: A cataract occurs when the eye’s natural lens becomes cloudy and is replaced with an artificial lens. Because the lens of your eye has been removed, you can’t ever develop cataracts again. You may, however develop what is called “secondary cataract,” which is treated with a laser in an office setting in a minute or two.

answer_links.text: A cataract occurs when the eye’s natural lens becomes cloudy
“secondary cataract,” which is treated with a laser in an office setting

title: What IOL is best if I’ve had a stroke?
question: I am planning for cataract surgery next spring and trying to compare the various IOLs as they would affect my balance problems from an old cerebellar stroke. Would it be useful for me to consult with a neurologist as I consider my options?
answer:
I don’t think most neurologists would have a deep understanding of IOL designs and their effects. The best physician to speak to about this is your cataract surgeon. If your old cerebellar stroke causes problems with your vision, balance or eye movements, your surgeon might consult a neuro-ophthalmologist. The simplest thing to do to minimize potential side effects after surgery would be to choose a monofocal lens or a toric lens (if you have astigmatism ).

While there is little clinical data that discusses multifocal IOLs and neurological disease, multifocals do occasionally create symptoms that in theory could worsen your existing visual function. Your cataract surgeon will be able to help you decide on the best IOL option for your specific situation.

title: What is the best IOL choice for a pilot?
question: What is the best IOL choice for a pilot?
answer: With multifocal or accommodative lenses, you have to lay off flying for 3 months per FAA guidelines. Therefore, a traditional monofocal or toric (astigmatism correcting) lens would be in your best interest.

answer_links.text: traditional monofocal or toric (astigmatism correcting) lens

title: What is the best treatment option for corneal edema?
question: What is the best treatment option for corneal edema after cataract surgery in an 72-year-old diabetic woman?
answer:
Corneal edema (swelling of the clear, dome-shaped window at the front of the eye ) after cataract surgery is quite common as the cornea can take some time to recover. Depending on the cause, there are different treatments recommended. Usually, with enough time (a few weeks on average), all that is needed are the standard post-operative drops to relieve swelling. However, if someone has unresolved inflammation/edema inside the eye , the corneal swelling can linger, and steroid drops are recommended.

If the intraocular pressure is very high or very low, corneal edema can also occur. This should also be brought back into normal range with the right treatment.

Sometimes, special eye drops may be needed to pull the excess fluid out of the cornea. As a last resort, a corneal transplant can be performed to replace the damaged endothelial cells responsible for the swelling.

answer_links.text: clear, dome-shaped window at the front of the eye

title: What is the closest an IOL can be set for near vision?
question: What is the range of clear vision (inches from the eye) for an IOL that is set for near vision? As a photographer, I would like to have clear vision at a distance of six inches.
answer: Presbyopia-correcting IOLs have different set points for near depending on the manufacturer. Talk to your ophthalmologist about which of these would provide the closest near vision given your eye health and vision needs.

title: What is the recommended time to wait after bacterial blepharitis clears before having cataract surgery?
question: What is the recommended time to wait after bacterial blepharitis clears before having cataract surgery ?
answer: It is recommended that surgery be delayed by one week after the infection has cleared.

title: What is the wait time between cataract surgery and blepharoplasty?
question: How long after cataract surgery should you wait to have upper lid blepharoplasty?
answer: Generally, cataract surgeons recommend waiting 6 weeks or so before proceeding with additional surgery. This varies depending on how the surgery went and how the eye is healing, so the wait time is best determined by your surgeon(s).

title: What OTC eye drops can I use after my cataract surgery?
question: What over-the-counter eyedrops can I use after my cataract surgery ? I used the required prescription dosage before and right after surgery.
answer: If the eye is red or sore, sensitive to light, very irritated or getting blurry then you need to see your cataract surgeon for the appropriate treatment. If you are having mild symptoms of foreign body sensation, burning and/or tearing and your vision is stable and not worsening you can try any over-the-counter lubricating tear drop .

title: What are the risks of not removing a cataract?
question: What are some of the risks associated with not having a cataract removed? Can other damage occur as the cataract continues to get larger?
answer: The main risk of not having a cataract removed is that you will be living with compromised vision from the cataract that is known to result in a higher incidence of falls as well as other problems. If your vision is not bothersome and you feel you can get around and do all activities of daily living, there is no harm in waiting. It is possible to wait too long, making the cataract operation more difficult if the cataract becomes mature or very dense.

title: What's the difference between discission and cataract surgery?
question: What's the difference between discission and cataract surgery?
answer: Cataract surgery is a removal of the cloudy lens (one that has become less transparent) in the eye . Modern cataract surgery usually includes leaving the original "skin" of the back surface of the eye’s natural lens (called the "posterior capsule") in place in an effort to better support a plastic artificial intraocular lens ("implant") that replaces the cataract . In some cases, this capsule becomes cloudy, and a discission—creating an opening in the capsule so that light can better pass through it—can be made. This is usually accomplished with a laser and is called a "posterior capsulotomy."

answer_links.text: Cataract surgery is a removal of the cloudy lens (one that has become less transparent) in the eye
artificial intraocular lens ("implant") that replaces the cataract

title: What type of IOL should I get for myopia and astigmatism?
question: I wear glasses to correct myopia (nearsightedness) and astigmatism (irregularly shaped cornea) . My glasses are no-line progressive lenses and I’m planning to have cataract surgery now at age 74. I’m thinking I’ll choose either an IOL for near and intermediate vision and wear glasses for distance vision, or get an IOL for distance and use glasses for near/intermediate vision. I am likely to continue working and using a computer for another five years and I also read a lot. Which option do you think might work best?
answer:
It is not possible for me to tell you what intraocular lens (IOL) combination would work best for you, as this is a very personal decision. There are three basic ranges of vision: distance, intermediate and near. As it stands today, many intraocular lenses can provide excellent vision is any two of these three ranges, but none of the available intraocular lens provides excellent vision in all three ranges. There are many ways of using multifocal and monofocal lenses to deal with this problem:

- Multifocal IOL in each eye for distance and near with intermediate range glasses

- Multifocal IOL in each eye for distance and intermediate with near glasses

- Multifocal IOL in both eyes for distance and intermediate but deliberately setting the IOL power of the non-dominant a slight bit nearsighted which makes distance vision slightly blurry if the dominant eye is closed, but does not affect distance vision when using both eyes and gives a small boost for reading when both eyes are open.

- Multifocal IOL in each eye distance and intermediate, however, set such that the non-dominant eye’s distance vision is slightly off focus to the nearsighted side, allowing a boost for near vision.

- Monofocal IOL for distance in dominant eye and non-dominant eye set for intermediate. This is called mini-monovision.

And there are more options you should discuss with your ophthalmologist.

title: What viscoelastic gel can be used in the phacoemulsification stage of the surgery that does not have lidocaine in the gel?
question: You state that cataract surgery can be performed without using xylocaine (lidocaine) if one is allergic to it. What viscoelastic gel can be used in the phacoemulsification stage of the surgery that does not have lidocaine in the gel?
answer: The ocular viscoeleastic device does not contain lidocaine. As far as anesthesia is concerned there are other topical drops and injectible anesthetics that can give perfectly acceptable anesthesia for cataract surgery.

title: What will my range of focus be like if I have IOL set for near- or mid-range?
question: If I have the IOL implant lenses set for near- or mid-range, will the actual range of focus be any greater for near- or mid-work than it would be if the IOL lenses are set for distance? The main distances I need are: 14" (reading), 20" (playing the pipe organ), and 36" for reading student's music while teaching.
answer: The focal point will be very narrow for mid/near and distance will be blurry. If set for distance do not expect any near- or mid-distance. A multifocal lens may be a better choice for what you are seeking. Another option would be modified monovision, with one eye set for reading and the other set for intermediate – this might allow you to see at all three of your target ranges without glasses, but would require glasses correction for distance. Of course, your degree of astigmatism will affect the success of any implant lens scenario and may need correction with a toric lens or corneal procedure to achieve the best vision in your target range without glasses.

title: How soon after cataract surgery can posterior capsule opacity happen?
question: I was born with cataracts in both eyes. I had them removed in my teenage years and I am now 30 years old. Recently, my doctor checked and diagnosed me with posterior capsule opacity (PCO) and said I will need laser treatment. Is it really possible to have PCO so suddenly?
answer: A posterior capsular opacity is a clouding of the membrane that holds the intraocular lens in place. It is the back wall of the capsule that once enclosed your eye’s natural lens as well. A PCO does not come suddenly, but once the fibrosis covers a central area, it is time for a laser treatment. Everyone needs a laser treatment at some time. It is a very minor and quick procedure and may actually make your vision sharper.

title: When can my 8-month-old get IOLs after having cataracts removed at birth?
question: My 8-month-old baby had cataracts removed from both eyes and wears RGP contact lenses . At what age can IOLs be implanted?
answer: The timing of placing intraocular lenses (IOL) depends on the child and the condition of the eyes. If the child is doing well with contact lenses, then sometimes that is the best initial treatment. Placement of IOLs is typically withheld until 2 to 4 years of age. However, there may be factors that may limit the ability to place an IOL. For instance, the lens capsule that holds the IOL might not be able to support it. Or there may be other diseases affecting one or both eyes. It is always best to discuss this topic with your child's managing ophthalmologist who knows your child best.

answer_links.text: lens capsule that holds the IOL

title: When you have cataract surgery and they tell you that your distance vision will be good but you will need glasses to read, will you be able to work on a computer without glasses?
question: When you have cataract surgery and they tell you that your distance vision will be good but you will need glasses to read, will you be able to work on a computer without glasses, put on make-up without your glasses, etc.? I am kind of confused as to what my sight will be like after the surgery.
answer:
The lens of the eye changes shape when you switch what you are looking at—from things that are far away to things that are very close (and at every point in between those two). A cataract is a clouding of the focusing lens . The cataract lens cannot be cleaned. It must be removed.

In the old days, people had to wear very thick eyeglasses to make up for the lost focusing power of the human focusing lens. Today we replace the human lens with an artificial lens placed inside the eye called an IOL (intraocular lens) .

We have a great variety of IOL options and these choices can be very confusing. The standard IOL that most insurance companies pay for has a single focus that you and your ophthalmologist agree upon. There are three basic zones of vision: far (driving), intermediate (computer) and near (reading).

A standard IOL gives you one of these three zones and the other two usually require eyeglasses to achieve good vision. Other factors such as pupil size and the amount of light available can impact how well these people see for the other two zones of vision. Targeting that focus is not a perfectly accurate process, but usually the result is very close to your desired single visual goal.

Most patients request their IOL focus to be for distance and understand they will need glasses for computer and near vision. Some patients ask for near vision and are willing to wear glasses to see far. Some patients choose mini-monovision, such that one eye is focused for far and the other eye is focused for intermediate vision like computer distance. This requires further conversation with your ophthalmologist.

More recently we have premium/multifocal IOLs that do a good job of approaching normal vision of far, intermediate and near vision, but none of them are perfect. These premium/multifocal IOLs are usually only partially covered by insurance and the patient must pay for the difference in cost between the standard IOL and the premium/multifocal IOL.

I urge you to remember that no IOL guarantees perfect vision at all vision zones and under all conditions, but they do provide good to excellent visual results for most people.

answer_links.text: A cataract is a clouding of the focusing lens

title: Which type of cataract surgery is better with dry eye?
question: I have cataracts , dry eyes , and astigmatism . I am confused as to whether laser or traditional cataract surgery is best for me with my dry eyes. Is there a significant difference between them in regard to post-operative vision and dry eye symptoms?
answer:
Some physicians prefer laser–assisted cataract surgery , and some do not.

The data do not yet show a clear benefit of one over the other. More important here is that you identify your goals and if you want better uncorrected distance vision you may consider a toric IOL to correct astigmatism. If you would like to possibly be much freer from glasses and read without glasses, then a toric IOL that is also a multifocal or extended depth of focus toric lens may be able to accomplish this.

Once you decide on your IOL, then laser assisted or conventional surgery are both fine and you can decide with your surgeon.

title: Why am I sensitive to light after combined cataract-glaucoma surgery?
question: Any reason for the intense light sensitivity after combined cataract-glaucoma surgery with stents (small device that helps lower intraocular pressure) implanted ? It’s been two months with very little improvement.
answer: Light sensitivity after cataract surgery is not a rare complaint. People experience this to varying degrees because of both inflammation (swelling), and because with removal of the cataract, more light is able to enter your eye. For some, removing a cataract is like having a brown pair of sunglasses removed for the first time in many years. You should adjust some over time, but may always need sunglasses in brighter environments. Check with your ophthalmologist , but I think it is unlikely the light sensitivity has anything to do with the glaucoma stents.

title: Why are multifocal IOLs not recommended for me?
question: I'm 64 and a monofocal lens is recommended due to dense cataracts and destabilizing supporting structures inside the eye. Is this a good reason not to go with multifocal or accommodative lenses? How does the multifocal lens differ from the monofocal, with respect to the supporting structures of the eye?
answer:
must be placed in a secure

and well-centered. If the “supporting structures” (presumably of the capsular bag) are inadequate, then a multifocal IOL may not be the best idea. Your surgeon may also be concerned about the lens becoming dislocated and moving in ensuing years. Small dislocations may create significantly more symptoms in a patient with a multifocal lens.

answer_links.text: capsular bag (or lens capsule, the thin membrane securing the eye’s natural lens that’s left intact after surgery to hold the IOL)

title: Why can't my cataracts be removed now?
question: and want them removed, although my doctor said removal is not medically necessary. I am experiencing glare during night driving, blurry vision, and watery eyes. Why would I be required to wait for surgery?
answer:
The decision about timing for cataract surgery is usually made based on three factors: your symptoms, your measured visual acuity (with and without glare), and the appearance of your cataract. If all three factors suggest your cataract is the primary cause for your visual difficulties, then surgery is a reasonable option to improve your vision and is generally covered by your insurance (or “medically necessary” to improve your vision). Cataracts can technically be removed when they are very early, but if the three factors to not meet certain criteria, then your insurance may not agree with the decision for surgery, and you may have to pay out-of-pocket.

In your situation, the watery eyes are not a cataract symptom, but if the glare with night driving and the blurry vision are not improved with new glasses and the surgeon can document that your eyes are otherwise normal and your vision (with or without glare testing) is less than 20/20 , then cataract surgery is typically an option.

answer_links.text: The decision about timing for cataract surgery
vision (with or without glare testing) is less than 20/20

title: Why didn’t my toric lens fully correct my astigmatism?
question: I had a toric Symfony lens implanted in both eyes . In one eye I still have the same astigmatism I had before the implant. The surgeon is recommending a limbal relaxing incision surgery. I am having a lot of night aberrations. He thinks this could help. Is it possible for LRI to help the night issues and is this the best approach to correct the astigmatism? I'm confused why the toric lens did not correct the astigmatism in the first place.
answer:
A toric lens implant is an excellent way to correct limited amounts of the most common type of astigmatism (an irregularly shaped cornea that distorts vision) in a patient who is going to have cataract surgery . The implant lens must be positioned exactly for your astigmatism. One of the problems with any toric lens is that they might shift position in the early days after surgery, reducing the desired effect. Sometimes the cataract incision changes the astigmatism from the preoperative measurements, thus changing the effect of the toric lens you are given.

LRIs (limbal relaxing incisions, incisions made between the cornea and white of the eye to correct astigmatism) were used before toric implants were perfected and are another method of treating astigmatism. LRIs can be used without entering the inside of the eye, but work best for fairly small amounts of astigmatism. LRIs don't rotate like toric lenses can do.

Sometimes we use both torics and LRIs when the astigmatism is greater than the toric can correct.

If you want to avoid glasses or contact lenses, the solution your eye surgeon advises is your only option without going inside your eye again. When weighing the risks and benefits, it is recommended that the surgeon not go inside the eye again and instead have the LRI.

If aberrations such as halo and glare are the major issues, correction of the astigmatism may not take care of this. Some patients with multifocal or extended depth- of-focus lenses do not adapt to the optics of the lens. If this is the case, removal and replacement of the lens with a traditional monofocal lens may be the best solution. If the amount of your residual astigmatism is low, this may be the best solution for you. Please discuss with your surgeon. This question was originally answered on October 3, 2017.

answer_links.text: astigmatism (an irregularly shaped cornea that distorts vision)

title: Why do binoculars eliminate my IOL halos?
question: I have minor halos from multifocal IOLs. My vision is awesome at all distances except for the halos. However, I noticed that when looking through binoculars, the halos vanish. What is it about the binoculars that causes this and are there glasses I could buy to get the same effect?
answer:
The halos are related to the intraocular lens (IOL) design, which has circular rings of correction. The binoculars cut off the external (non-parallel) rays of light from entering the eye. This decreases the amount of light hitting the peripheral rings of correction in the IOL.

There is really no way to do this with any glasses, but you may ask your surgeon to prescribe some drops that you can use to make the pupil smaller. This may decrease but not eliminate the halos.

title: Why do I have balance/dizziness problems after cataract surgery?
question: Why do I have balance/dizziness problems after cataract surgery ?
answer:
Depending on the type of anesthesia (painkiller) used during the operation, one can experience balance problems and dizziness after surgery, but this typically would only last a few hours.

Persistent dizziness can be related to the new artificial lens that was implanted after removal of your eye's cloudy natural lens . The new artificial lens (IOL) may have a different refractive power from your previous lens and may be creating an imbalance to which you are unaccustomed. It also could be that the dizziness is completely unrelated to your surgery. You should report these symptoms to your surgeon who can investigate further.

This question was originally answered on Aug. 3, 2016.

title: Why do I have to have LASIK done after I have had YAG surgery?
question: Why do I have to have LASIK done after I have had YAG surgery ? I had a lens for distance implanted during cataract surgery . After the YAG, my vision is still blurry, and I cannot focus. Now they want to do LASIK. Is this normal?
answer: Yes, if the target was not hit with your lens implant to begin with, it is typical to perform the YAG to see if it changes the vision. If not, then LASIK is an excellent way to fine tune the final result .

answer_links.text: LASIK is an excellent way to fine tune the final result

title: Why do I see a distinctive black “C” in my vision after having a toric lens implanted?
question: I had a toric intraocular lens implanted which corrected my astigmatism and cataract in my left eye. My vision is terrific but it looks like I'm wearing a contact lens that has a distinctive black “C” on it. It does not affect my vision, but it does not seem "normal." It almost seems like someone took a black sharpie marker and drew on the left edge of the lens. Do I need a replacement?
answer: What you are describing is known as a negative dysphotopsia—an unusual reflection image. Replacement does not always fix the problem, but time usually makes it go away. Another option can be the insertion of what is called a piggyback lens which can negate the image. Talk to your surgeon about the options.

title: Why do I see halos with my multifocal lens?
question: I just had a Panoptics lens put in a week and a half ago and I notice that I have a small crescent moon to the right. Letters have a slight glow or fuzz to them, and I have pretty severe halo effect at night and the street signs have a glow around them. Should I give it some time to change and how long? Or should I start planning on removing it and have a plain lens put in?
answer: With the Panoptix lens or any multifocal lens , it is normal to have some glow as well as halos for the first six weeks or so. They generally tend to get better but do not completely go away. The small crescent moon may be what we call a negative dysphotopsia. This can happen with many IOLs and also should get better with time. Of course, if the visual symptoms do not improve over time, you will need to discuss alternatives including removal and replacement of the lens although this is rarely necessary.

answer_links.text: Panoptix lens or any multifocal lens

title: Why has my near vision gotten worse since my cataract surgery two weeks ago?
question: My near vision has gotten worse since my cataract surgery from two weeks ago and it feels totally different than my other eye. What is the problem?
answer: If you had a monofocal lens implanted (single focus lens), your area of best focus will be determined by the power chosen for this eye. If you have concerns, ask your operating surgeons what options you have in the future for better near vision if that is what you desire.

title: Why have I experienced leaky eyes since having my cataracts removed?
question: Why have I experienced leaky eyes since having my cataracts removed? This has caused a dryness to eyelids as well as swelling and redness around my eyes.
answer: This is not typically associated with cataract surgery . I would check with your ophthalmologist to see if there is a blocked tear drainage duct that is causing the issue. This can be fixed if it is the problem.

title: Why is a multifocal lens implant not possible after vitrectomy/scleral buckle surgery?
question: Why is a multifocal lens implant not possible after vitrectomy and scleral buckle surgery (surgery that helps reattach the retina, or light sensitive tissue, to the back of the eye)? I will be having a cataract removed (surgery to replace eye’s cloudy natural lens with clear artificial lens) eventually and might prefer this to monovision .
answer: This can depend on a number of things. If the macula (center of the retina) was damaged by the retinal detachment or hole , multifocal lenses are not recommended as they can actually make vision worse since they decrease the amount of incoming light. Also, if there was damage to the posterior capsule of the lens during the vitrectomy , there would not be a support structure to hold this type of lens in place. It is best to ask your surgeon what he recommends and why.

title: Why is my eye tearing after cataract surgery?
question: I had cataract surgery a year ago and one of my eyes has been watering continuously almost every day for the last six months. I wake up with that eye extremely crusted at times and a thick film over it that I cannot see through until I am up and blinking it for a few minutes, then it starts watering again. Can you give me an idea of what to do?
answer: This may be due to a blockage in the tear drainage duct in the eyelid . I would see your eye surgeon to evaluate this. There is surgery to correct this, which is usually performed by an oculoplastic surgeon.

answer_links.text: blockage in the tear drainage duct in the eyelid

title: Why is my vision not sharp after cataract surgery?
question: It’s been three years since my cataract surgery and I have multifocal lenses. I have readers and distance vision is not sharp. What can I do for blurriness in the intermediate range (like the automobile dashboard)?
answer:
Results like this are not common but do happen with all types of IOLs after cataract surgery . A comprehensive ophthalmic exam specifically looking for dry eyes , other problems with the cornea at the front of the eye, clouding behind the IOLs (known as posterior capsule opacification ), or problems with the retina in the back of the eye is recommended. If anything is found that can be treated, such as dry eyes, the treatment should be maximized.

Next, the refractive error should be tested and then corrected with the proper spectacles (perhaps a low addition progressive), or even laser vision correction . If there is no eye disease and your distance vision is not acceptable even with glasses, then, in very rare cases, multifocal implants can be exchanged for monofocals, as long as the patient realizes they will not be independent of glasses.

answer_links.text: the retina in the back of the eye
refractive error should be tested and then corrected with the proper spectacles

title: Why is my vision still blurry after having cataract surgery a year ago?
question: Why is my vision still blurry after having cataract surgery a year ago?
answer: Persistent blurry vision after cataract surgery can be due to many different things. Some causes may relate to the surgery and others, such as macular degeneration among others, are unrelated to the surgery. See your ophthalmologist for a comprehensive exam to find the cause and the appropriate treatment.

title: Why is reading more difficult several years after my cataract surgery?
question: Several years ago, I had cataract surgery and lens replacement . What can I do now that reading has become more of a problem? I had the trifocal lens installed.
answer: If this was several years ago, I would have your surgeon look at your measurements again, do a dilated examination and see if the capsule holding the lens implant in place has clouded (may need a laser treatment). This is normal for many people after cataract surgery. The capsule is treated with a laser (called a posterior capsulotomy) that helps restore clear vision.

answer_links.text: The capsule is treated with a laser (called a posterior capsulotomy)

title: Why is saline used during cataract surgery?
question: Why is saline used during cataract surgery?
answer:
It’s not exactly saline but it is called balanced salt solution. There needs to be a fluid inflow during cataract surgery to keep the eye pressurized . A saline type solution is more compatible with the existing fluid in the eye called aqueous humor .

If one were to use sterile water with no salt then it could chemically damage the cornea . It can also permanently damage the very sensitive endothelial cells of the cornea that are required to pump water out of the cornea to maintain its clarity.

answer_links.text: There needs to be a fluid inflow during cataract surgery

title: Why is there a clear mucosal film over a portion of my eye after cataract surgery?
question: I'm 70 years old and just recently had cataract surgery in both eyes. One eye is fine but the other has what I would call a clear mucosal film over a portion of my eye. I can wipe it away with my finger but after a few minutes it comes back. I did not have this problem prior to the surgery. Could you please tell me what is going on?
answer: There is no way to tell without an exam. This could be a conjunctivitis or a blocked tear duct or something completely different. It is not a symptom of a complication of cataract surgery. Please have your surgeon re-examine your eye.

title: Why is there such a great difference in cost to patient between putting in regular lens for cataracts versus toric for astigmatism?
question: Why is there such a great difference in cost to patient between putting in regular lens for cataracts versus toric for astigmatism ? It seems to be same operation.
answer:
The issue is that the lens itself is more expensive by many times and is not reimbursed by insurance. Plus, more pre-operative measurements and calculations are needed and the follow-up after surgery can be more involved. Even the surgery itself can be different: The capsulotomy (or opening the anterior lens capsule) is lens specific. The eye has to be specifically marked for the axis correction of the toric lens, and sometimes an aberrometer (a special device that measures the way light travels through your eye) is used to make sure the lens is correctly placed.

Though the operation is very similar, there are some important differences that do add cost to the procedure.

title: Why would a doctor place a contact lens on a patient’s eye after cataract surgery?
question: Why would a doctor place a contact lens on a patient’s eye after cataract surgery?
answer: There are several reasons an ophthalmologist might put a contact lens on a patient after cataract surgery . A person might have sustained drying of the surface of the eye (the cornea) during the operation and a "bandage" soft contact lens could make the eye more comfortable while the results of the drying heal. Some ophthalmologists place a bandage contact lens on an eye after cataract surgery, like we use a band-aid normally, to protect the small incision where the cataract surgery took place. Another reason is that a bandage contact lens can help antibiotic eye drops used after surgery remain in the eye longer and not be washed out as rapidly by tears.

title: Why would someone with an IOL need LASIK on the same eye four weeks later?
question: Why would someone with an IOL (artificial intraocular lens placed in eye after cataract removal surgery) need LASIK on the same eye four weeks later?
answer: No one has to have LASIK after cataract surgery , but if not all of your myopia (nearsightedness) , hyperopia (farsightedness) or astigmatism (irregularly shaped cornea) could be corrected with the IOL, LASIK can be used to fine tune the visual result.

title: Will cataract surgery affect development of dry AMD in that eye?
question: Will cataract surgery to my right eye, which is in the beginning stage of dry AMD, have any effect on the further development of my dry AMD in that eye?
answer: This is an important question that has been asked by many. There’s no evidence that the surgery should affect your AMD, but it’s important for your retinal specialist to be sure that you have no signs of occult neovascularization (abnormal blood vessels that grown inside the eye when one has wet AMD) prior to surgery.

title: Will cataract surgery help with my watering eyes?
question: I have a weeping left eye and normally watery eyes. I’ve just been diagnosed with cataracts and require surgery. Will this help with the watering eyes?
answer:
Watery eye (or tearing) sounds like such a simple problem, but actually there are many causes of this condition. This can be due to excessive tear production or poor tear drainage .

Glare from cataracts can cause excessive tear production under certain lighting conditions but would not be expected in dimmer light. I am also concerned that you report cataracts in both eyes but only report excessive tearing in your left eye. It is possible that you have a tear drainage problem on the left. I would suggest that you speak with your ophthalmologist and ask him/her about your left eye tearing problem.

title: Will cataract surgery repair my worsening nearsightedness?
question: I had a macular hole repaired . In the year since, I have become more nearsighted in that eye (from 3 to 9). Will the cataract surgery I will need repair this and stop it from getting worse?
answer: After macular hole surgery, cataract formation and worsening of cataract are common. As the cataract forms, it generally induces more nearsightedness and that can be corrected with cataract surgery.

title: Will cataracts complicate my glaucoma visual field test?
question: Will a visual field test to check on my glaucoma be useful since I also have cataracts which affect my vision?
answer: It should be useful. Part of the software in the testing machine helps minimize the effects of the cataract.

title: Will DMSO for arthritis harm my IOL?
question: I use DMSO for arthritis and I need cataract surgery. Will DMSO harm the implant?
answer: DMSO, a cream that is applied to the skin, helps treat arthritis and is also used to help the body absorb other medications. It will have little effect on the eye once it enters your body and no effect on cataract removal surgery or your intraocular lens (the implant) . If DMSO helps your arthritis, carry on.

title: Will dull colors brighten after my second cataract surgery?
question: I had a cataract removed 3 months ago and noticed the yellow/brown tint I had been seeing disappeared and whites became bright! But after having my second eye done 3 days ago, and I’m seeing the dull yellow/brown colors again. Will this resolve or is something wrong?
answer: This may be temporary if your retina (light sensitive tissue in the back of the eye) is normal and without disease. If it continues, please have your surgeon re-evaluate.

answer_links.text: retina (light sensitive tissue in the back of the eye)

title: Will I become blind from delayed cataract surgery?
question: I am 62-year-old with diabetes and was diagnosed with cataract on one eye which worsened with time. My doctor scheduled surgery for this month, but it’s postponed indefinitely. My vision in the affected eye is totally blurred. Will I eventually become blind without surgery ?
answer: Without treatment, the vision will become worse in the affected eye. But the cataract can still be removed in the near future when elective surgery becomes more widely available. Despite its delay, cataract surgery will correct the vision impaired by the cataract. Hang in there, help for your vision is coming.

title: Will I need a new eye examination and new lenses after cataract surgery?
question: Will I need a new eye examination and new lenses after cataract surgery ?
answer: Yes. All measurements will usually change after your surgery and new glasses will be prescribed.

title: Will LASIK help my vision after cataract surgery?
question: within the last year. Is it possible to have LASIK surgery now to reduce my dependence on glasses? I have astigmatism in both eyes.
answer: Depending on the type and amount of correction and the health of your corneas, LASIK is certainly a possibility . Schedule a discussion with your surgeon who can identify the best strategy to meet your visual goals given your eye health.

title: Will a monofocal IOL improve myopia as well as a toric IOL?
question: Will a monofocal IOL improve myopia as well as a toric IOL?
answer: Both a monofocal IOL and a toric IOL can correct myopia (nearsightedness) . However, if you have astigmatism, your vision without glasses will be better with a toric IOL than with a monofocal IOL. The toric lens can correct both myopia and astigmatism while the monofocal lens can only address the myopia.

answer_links.text: Both a monofocal IOL and a toric IOL

title: Will my astigmatism be different after having cataract surgery?
question: I need cataract surgery . I've been told that I have astigmatism (irregularly shaped cornea) in both the back of my eyes and front of my eyes but that these offset each other which explains why my glasses only have a relatively small astigmatism adjustment of 0.25. Should I anticipate that my astigmatism will be different after IOL implants ?
answer: You may need a toric lens to correct your astigmatism , since the internal astigmatism created by the lens of your eye (the cataract ) will be removed. Please discuss this with your surgeon to see what your options are.

title: Will my aunt’s surgery be successful if she refuses eye drops afterwards?
question: My disabled aunty had cataract surgery but is refusing to let anyone put in the eye drops. Will the operation still be successful without her using them?
answer: Of course, it is best that all drops are used to prevent infection and inflammation . If she is not using the drops I suggest you call her doctor ASAP and see what else can be done. If you can teach her to put her own drops in, maybe she would accept that?

title: Will my IOL correct my lazy eye after cataract surgery?
question: My eyeglass prescription straightens my lazy eye. If I get cataract surgery, will it also correct my lazy eye?
answer:
The short answer is that if someone were to have cataract surgery , and the refractive correction they were using in their glasses is now transferred to an intraocular lens , most but not all of the time the strabismus (misaligned or “crossed” eyes) control will be about the same. There are some patients whose strabismus control worsens, and this is something to discuss with your surgeon before cataract surgery.

If the question pertains to prism correction (special glasses that are used to correct double vision) , the prism cannot be transferred into the intraocular lens. So, prism glasses will be needed after cataract surgery.

One thing to consider when discussing glasses use after cataract surgery with "lazy eye," is what type of lazy eye you have. If it is strabismus, then sometimes glasses will not be needed, and the strabismus control will remain the same. This is not always the case but most of the time does hold true. If by lazy eye you mean “amblyopia” , then cataract surgery may partially but not completely improve the vision. Depending on the severity of the amblyopia, cataract surgery may not improve the vision at all. For patients with moderate to severe amblyopia, they should always plan on wearing glasses after cataract surgery as the glasses protect their healthy "good" eye from injury. They will always need eye protection.

answer_links.text: prism correction (special glasses that are used to correct double vision)

title: Will my IOLs work in tandem with my contact lenses after cataract surgery?
question: I am 29 and I have cataracts . I work with computers, so I’ve decided to get an under-corrected monofocal intraocular lens for near vision. Currently, I wear contacts to see far. I also wear these contacts while I work on my computer. After cataract surgery, will I still be able to wear contacts to see far and see my computer at the same time? In other words, will my IOLs work in tandem with my contacts lenses or would I need them taken off to see my computer?
answer: These are common choices that all cataract patients need to make. You may want to consider an extended depth-of-focus lens. This will give you a continuous focus from close, intermediate (computer), and far away—perhaps requiring reading glasses for very fine print or in dim lighting. If you go with under-correction, you will need bifocals to see both near and distance at the same time. Contacts can be worn, but unless you wear multifocal contacts, which do not work for everyone, you can either see far or near, not both. Another option is monovision—one eye for distance and one eye for near or intermediate, but not all people adapt to this choice. You should discuss these options in detail with your cataract surgeon.

title: Will my near vision be better or worse without glasses after cataract surgery?
question: I'm farsighted and wear tri-focal glasses. I'm having a cataract removed and replaced with a lens where I won't need glasses for distance. Will my near vision be better or worse without glasses?
answer: I need to see your eyeglasses prescription before any surgery to be able to answer accurately. In most cases, farsighted people will be less farsighted after cataract surgery with a lens implant and most of the time that will make the required glasses for reading and for computer less strong. That would consequently mean that your unaided reading and computer distance vision would be somewhat improved, but not perfect by any means. I suggest you discuss this with your ophthalmologist.

title: Will a new IOL help my vision after having a cataract removed at age 3?
question: Have cataract surgery techniques improved sufficiently in the past 20 years to consider having a new intraocular lens (IOL) placed to improve eyesight, and is this even possible? I was diagnosed with and operated for a congenital cataract 20 years ago at age 3. A monofocal IOL was placed, and I now see 60 percent from my left eye. Though I am very glad to see anything from that eye at all, I lack depth perception, I can’t read with the affected eye, and regularly worry about the consequences if something were to happen to my other eye. As such, I was wondering whether any significant improvement can be made in terms of eyesight through a repeat surgery.
answer: Significant improvements have been made in IOLs, but nothing that is likely to help your problem. If your childhood cataract led to a loss of vision from amblyopia (when vision is one or both eyes don’t develop normally during childhood) , an intraocular lens would be unable to improve this deficit. Check with your local ophthalmologist to be sure.

answer_links.text: amblyopia (when vision is one or both eyes don’t develop normally during childhood)

title: Is there any risk that rubbing my eyes will dislodge the IOL?
question: After cataract surgery , is there any risk to dislodging the IOLs from rubbing my eyes in the morning due to excessive tearing?
answer:
While eye rubbing is generally discouraged right after cataract surgery, doing so will not cause an intraocular lens (IOL) to move out of position after an uncomplicated cataract surgery once the eye is well-healed.

There are no hard rules here so I would recommend asking your ophthalmologist what their preference is regarding this.

title: Will secondary cataract surgery worsen my AMD?
question: Will a laser procedure on a secondary cataract possibly worsen macular degeneration?
answer: There is little evidence to suggest that correcting a secondary cataract with laser ( posterior capsulotomy ) can make your AMD (age-related macular degeneration) worse. Your visual improvement from the laser could be limited by the AMD, but the laser is not likely to worsen the AMD.

title: Will sodium chloride solution resolve corneal edema after cataract surgery?
question: Is applying sodium chloride solution only a temporary relief for cornea edema after cataract surgery or will it permanently resolve this problem?
answer: Sodium chloride drops and/or ointment help remove fluid from the cornea that causes the “edema” or swelling. Topical steroids are also helpful. Corneal edema after cataract surgery usually resolves completely with time and use of the medications. Rarely, removing a very large cataract with preexisting corneal diseases such as Fuchs’ dystrophy can prevent the edema from resolving. In these cases, a procedure known as endothelial keratoplasty can be performed to cure the corneal edema.

title: With my vision changing so rapidly, how will I choose an intraocular lens after cataract surgery two years from now?
question: I'm 46. My eyes are changing so rapidly that I'm buying new glasses every year (not small tweaks). Right now I'm 20/400 walking around in 20/300 lenses from last February. I have cataracts and will have surgery in a couple of years. With my eyes not being stable, how do I choose an IOL ?
answer: Once you are 20 or over, the changes that occur in your glasses are mostly likely due to changes in the lens of your eye —the very thing that has reduced your vision with cataract at this time. These changes have no bearing on the IOL choice since once the lens is removed (the cataract is the lens), the changing part of your problem will be gone. The IOL choice will be based on other things unique to your eyes and you should ask your ophthalmologist what lenses you can consider.

title: Would a cataract surgeon be able to identify a rotated IOL during an examination?
question: Would a cataract surgeon be able to identify a rotated IOL during an examination?
answer: Assuming you are talking about a toric lens (astigmatism-correcting IOL) being possibly rotated, the answer is yes. As long as the pupil is dilated wide enough to get a good look , this should not be a problem.

answer_links.text: dilated wide enough to get a good look

title: Would cataracts cause me to see completely different colors?
question: I have cataracts, which affect my vision, however I now see completely different colors versus subtly different hues of the same color I had seen previously. These stark differences come and go, but generally happen when I first wake up. Can I chalk this up to cataracts and old age creeping in?
answer: Cataracts can cause changes in color perception as they progress . The variability may be due to pupil size, lighting or dry eyes . Most likely these symptoms are due to progression of your cataracts. However, please consult with your ophthalmologist to confirm this because retina and optic nerve problems in the back of the eye can also cause these changes.

answer_links.text: Cataracts can cause changes in color perception as they progress

title: Can YAG cause starbursts around lights?
question: Can YAG treatment cause you to see huge starbursts around lights at night? I have a light-adjustable lens (LAL).
answer: The YAG treatment (or posterior capsulotomy) should not have anything to do with seeing starbursts around lights at night . The light-adjustable lens should not cause much in the way of halo or starburst, either. Check with your surgeon so they can investigate what might be responsible for this symptom.
